body: @theharshbhatia no, I am waiting for openwhisk developer's response.

This looks to be a breaking change to existing CLI behavior.  Currently, the `--docker` flag is a boolean; with this PR the `--docker` flag will take an argument.  With this change will existing scripts that leverage the `--docker` flag break?

@rabbah 
>I think this merge is problematic. It created a situation where all the cli tests are in the core repo. So we cannot accept any cli changes because of a circular dependence we can't break easily when cli changes are also required. So for example if there is a cli change and accompanying test changes, the tests in the core repo will be incompatible with the cli version pulled from the cli repo. I think we need to continue building the cli from this local copy until such time when all the accompanying tests are moved to the cli repo.

I agree with further inspecting the other repos.
I think before we start using the two cli repos we need a better testing story.
We have two repos to deal with 
- https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-client-go
- https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-cli

For both there should be tests on the repo, and travis integration that takes the source from the same repo and run tests that are located in the sam repo.

As a transition we should duplicate the tests from core to both, and evaluate which set goes where.

Also provide docs for a contributor on how to setup their dev environment and do testing locally

I proposed we revert this change, and what we can do is introduce a mode for the cli ansible role, where we can pass a flag to do the new behavior to allow experimentation and integration into the other cli repos.

Some context on this revert here:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2345#issuecomment-308410151

@anasanjaria what are you waiting on ?

Configuring the docker deamon, follow by a restart it's what the script does today
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tools/ubuntu-setup/docker.sh#L27
```
sudo service docker restart
```
I recently merge a change that to all.sh that all script run sequentially no more async, hope this helps with some of the inconsistencies

If one used `--docker` as `wsk action create example --docker janesmith/blackboxdemo` then there is no effect with the proposed change. I'll call this the `conforming` case.

If on the other had the `--docker` option was used any where else, then yes such commands may no longer work.

I have no evidence to suggest the common case is the  `conforming` case, but I think it is. It's too bad we don't have semantic versioning for the CLI.

What do you suggest @mdeuser? Using a different flag (`--image`?) or accepting that this is a breaking change?
Does this replace https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2284?
I prefer avoiding breaking CLI changes.  Is the intent of this new option to allow for 1 or more files to be "copied" somewhere into the action runtime folder - regardless of the runtime?

Yes that is the intent. `wsk action create foo --kind nodjes:6 my.zip` and `wsk action create bar --docker imagename my.zip` become the same API call.

I don't think I want to introduce another option but if we did would we call it `--image`?
```
wsk action create foo bar --docker # as today
wsk action create foo --docker bar # as today 
wsk action create foo --image bar my.zip # new feature
```

For current zip files we require that you must specify a zip file but there is still some divergence:
```
wsk action create foo --kind docker bar my.zip

vs.
wsk action create foo --kind nodjes:6 my.zip

but
wsk action create foo --kind nodjes:6 my.zip
wsk action create foo --image bar my.zip

for which one could view --kind nodejs:6 as syntactic sugar for
wsk action create foo --image openwhisk/nodejs6action bar my.zip
```

Maybe I can preserve the existing behavior where `--docker` accepts an optional argument and in the absence of one, the artifact name is used as today. This seems like unnecessary complexity though. What do you suggest?
@akrabat ^^
with `--image` and `--docker` being redundant, I'd want to deprecate the latter we shouldn't have two ways of doing the same thing.

@rabbah   
yes ... replacement for #2284 ( can be closed )
@rabbah Yes, I did run `./tools/macos/tweak-dockermachine.sh`. Is that the step you're referring to?

@rabbah @csantanapr How do we define the CLI test cases in openwhisk? Based on my observation, all the test cases use “val wsk = new Wsk” to interact with openwhisk services, for example, whisk.core.database.test.CacheConcurrencyTests. Is this test cases also cli test case and does it need to be moved to cli repo?

There are some tests which are CLI specific as in `WskBasicUsage` and `WskBasicTests` but almost all our tests go through the CLI vs the API. For the sake of the CLI repos, i think you’ll have to iterate to figure out what is actually testing CLI functionality and what isn’t. 

The core repo should perhaps not use the CLI for tests at all since that’s an external dependence, and instead drive all tests through the API; this could be done by injecting a new `Wsk` implementation for example which instead of calling out to the CLI, makes a REST call. I offer no evidence this will be easy to do, but I think is doable and could be one way to approach the separation.

@markusthoemmes was going to remove the IBM header in a separate "phase" once all repos. were similarly updated.  Phase 1 is pointing this repo. (and others that currently scan) to the version in "utils" ... https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2365 "Reference scancode from utils repo. but preserve local copy (phase 1)"

and was being cautious in this PR as to to easily see that all the 225 files only had header/comment changes.  This also follows Carlos' advice given in another PR when we tried to remove local scancode previously (to instead go in phases).

Opened the following issue in utils to track Phase 2 removal of local scancode and Phase 3 removal of IBM headers:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/2376 "Phase 2: Remove scancode from openwhisk repo." and https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-utilities/issues/10 "Phase 3: Remove IBM license header"
Please note that I am privately working on a PyPi package for scancode which in the future could be used in place of a "clone".

there are also many external repos that depend on openwhisk to use the cli based test utilities that it currently provides.  they will also need to be updated to use the new REST based utils in openwhisk if the cli stuff is all moved out.

Yes - can you verify the TLS setting stuck?

That is check `/var/lib/boot2docker/profile` inside your [docker-machine](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tools/macos/tweak-dockermachine.sh#L10) and confirm 
`DOCKER_TLS=no` appears there.

Here is what I see:
```
docker@whisk:~$ sudo cat /var/lib/boot2docker/profile

EXTRA_ARGS='
--label provider=virtualbox

'
CACERT=/var/lib/boot2docker/ca.pem
DOCKER_HOST='-H tcp://0.0.0.0:2376'
DOCKER_STORAGE=aufs
DOCKER_TLS=auto
SERVERKEY=/var/lib/boot2docker/server-key.pem
SERVERCERT=/var/lib/boot2docker/server.pem


DOCKER_TLS=no
DOCKER_HOST='-H tcp://0.0.0.0:4243'
EXTRA_ARGS='--userns-remap=default'
DOCKER_TLS=no
DOCKER_HOST='-H tcp://0.0.0.0:4243'
EXTRA_ARGS='--userns-remap=default'
DOCKER_TLS=no
```

@bigmianhua have you tried the following procedure by building the .zip in the target environment rather than on the client environment?
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/docs/actions.md#packaging-python-actions-with-a-virtual-environment-in-zip-files

especially using this command:
```
docker run --rm -v "$PWD:/tmp" openwhisk/python3action sh \
  -c "cd tmp; virtualenv virtualenv; source virtualenv/bin/activate; pip install -r requirements.txt;"
```

It seems the issue is resolved...restarting the Mac OS host setup process and initially SSH-ing into the machine (after running `./tools/macos/tweak-dockermachine.sh`) then deleting the line `DOCKER_TLS=auto` made my `docker ps` run fine, and so far, `./gradlew distDocker` run fine as well. Because `DOCKER_TLS=no` gets appended to `/var/lib/boot2docker/profile` after the `auto` line, it should override it, and this shouldn't be the reason `gradlew` works for me now...but it does.

@rabbah is there anything else pending for this PR to get merged? I suggest merging it and (like many other things already in the system), refactoring to pluggable nature once a pattern for that is established. If there is concern about the weight of dependencies added here, let's discuss, but it seems a limited change in that way, and configurable to disable side affects if desired (and disabled state is default)

Summarizing discussion on Slack with @mdeuser and @dubeejw:

1. there is a strong preference to preserve `--docker` and not break behavior
`wsk action create name image --docker`
2. there is preference to add second position argument which if present is the zip file for the docker action 
`wsk action create name image [zipfile] --docker`
3. add new option `--image` which accepts an image name and positional argument is the zip file; this preserves `--docker` behavior
`wsk action create name [zipfile] --image image`
4. add `--docker` with `--image` to specify the image name and positional argument is the zip file 
`wsk action create name [zipfile] --docker --image image`
5. add `--kind docker` with `--image` to specify the image name, and positional argument is the zip file
`wsk action create name [zipfile] --kind docker --image image`
6. make a breaking change so that the docker flag takes an artifact which is this PR in its current state
`wsk action create name [zipfile] --docker image`

I already raised some objections to these changes. I'll summarize them:

1. the added overhead on the activation message in space means messages that were already working will no longer work in a production system for the same payload; this is a concern
2. will need a test to ensure that whatever the desired invariant are from the sampling is actually being captured
3. in addition to a test for the sampling itself, we need a test to confirm that when the sample rate is 0 (ie no tracing), the size of the activation message is not affected

I have a general concern about accepting one-offs and deferring the refactoring. Who's committing to doing the refactoring? Further, as I noticed, in some deployments, this will not be enabled at all. So we are incurring additional overhead for some deployments without articulating the gains. I think we have to be extra vigilant on this point as we have more contributors now and more community partners and just today there was a discussion about just this PR and why the OpenTracing (http://opentracing.io/) is not used instead of a direct integration. 

I have only made a cursory pass over the code but if you want to pursue this in its current form, I think I and others will likely want to make a more critical pass over the actual code.
Glad you got it working. Do you think I should close this issue or is there something for us to fix (in which case, might you be interested in contributing a patch)?
PG approved.

I'm echoing @tysonnorris's suggestion to go ahead and merge. Myself, my team for instance, are currently blocked by this. We need this information in order to understand performance bottlenecks, and make performance suggestions and improvements. We also need a measurable and reproducible way to see the impact of any change we make in all our deployments and environments.   

Pragmatically speaking if we want pluggability, then we're blocking this PR for an unknown amount of time.
 
For now, I think that, if we could agree on items 2. and 3. that you mentioned, which seem like a good way to manage 1. (there's a flag to turn tracing `off`) , then we might have something good enough to make progress.  We can always refactor it later, after the pluggability feature is in.

Great that you will add tests (and as you noted the feature toggle is in place).

I'm curious, however, can you help me understand how this blocks your team - you can surely use this feature branch in your internal deployments, no? This in general concerns me in that I do not think we should set a precedent where we start accepting pull requests that are incomplete, works in progress, etc. because they are "blocking" certain private deployments. This should not be confused with a statement about the state of this particular pull request, or interpreted as a statement against staging commits to deliver new and potentially disruptive functionality in small self-contained drips for which this project has a strong history of doing. Perhaps this is a good discussion for the dev list.

I think the two options I will be OK will be with a modify version of 4 or 5

Propose modify versions where --image is optional, if not specify use the default value `openwhisk/dockerskeleton`
Option 4b
```
wsk action create name [zipfile] --docker [--image image]
```
Option 5b
```
wsk action create name [zipfile] --kind docker [--image image]
```
PG 2/1666 finally 🚀

OK option 4b is invalid
```
wsk action create name [zipfile] --docker [--image image]
```
Because user can use `wsk action create name path/file --docker` and we don't know if `path/file` is a path to the zip/archive or an image name

I don't like option 3 too vague
```
wsk action create name [zipfile] --image image
```
I didn't realise there was an open issue for the new version of Swift which included these changes. That's a much better idea.
@akrabat I will try again I did a lot iterations, and capture some of the steps I got working.
it's blocking b/c the intent is to enable tracing not just during development, but in stage, load-test, and prod environments as well. maintaining a feature branch is not a simple option.
OK thanks. So we don't hijack this PR, I'll follow up separately on this point.

For now I think it can be closed, but I can try to recreate it in a new setup and see if changing the `./tools/macos/tweak-dockermachine.sh` script to remove the `DOCKER_TLS=auto` solves the issue from the start.

I think we found a better way to handle this
Increasing the size of the runtime image is the wrong direction we want to go, I'm actually looking into decreasing the size of the nodejs image.


We are trying to make it easier to add new kinds for the languages we already have in place.
This PR #2383 will take the list from group vars manifest in ansbile and docker pull those images into the invoker.

The way we can easily create an image that has a few packages more than the base nodejs, and be deploy in your environment, this would be something for operators to benefit, and then for users you would provide a new kind like `nodejs-acme:6` where this image extend `FROM` the base nodejs image but have more npm packages custom for acme.

There is a related PR #2112, that would allow users to use their own docker images that could extend one of the language ones and create actions with a docker image and a zip, not requiring the operator to pre-populate the images to the invokers. It would be giving an user to create their own kinds

In terms of nodejs actions use for building actions, they would require g++, git, and such so we are thinking on creating a new kind i.e. `action-nodejs-build-v6` were it doesn't matter if the image is bit big as it's not that critical for performance and is more important functionality for deployment time.
We are thinking instead of creating this new image on this repo, we start the process and create a new repo `openwhisk-runtimes` were we build the images from starting with the init/build actions per language.


cc @rabbah

@rabbah 
The ubuntu nodes in Apache Jenkins are shared between all projects and they don't provide root access and do not allow to change the default configuration. 
The default configuration is not configured for docker engine is not configure with http API enable on any port i.e 4243

We would need to change all the places we refer to the port to not use the http port and instead use the API over socket file device /var/... the same API that the docker CLI uses

On the surface, I'd say this is working as expected.  When a `-p` or `-a` flag is specified, the next two space-separated arguments are taken as the parameter key and value, respectively.  If they are valid JSON (object or string), then the command will not consider this an error.  In the examples above -b, -r, -p, and -a are all valid JSON strings and the command consumes them as such.

we’ve made breaking changes to the cli before - i feel like we’re obsessing over this small detail which i think will break very few users and is actually the best of all the options (option 6). I tried to preserve the old behavior and avoid adding a new parameter - it can’t be done easily and the refactoring was staring to pile up. I then implemented option 2 but don’t like it, i feel it’s prone to error and inconsistent with the other kinds. So since we don't have auto cli upgrades, those that don’t upgrade wont actually be broken at all. I therefore posit we should adopt the best option going forward and suggest that's option 6. I updated the documentation accordingly to include examples and a note on the new behavior.

OK I think the return on investment is too high, I'm OK with option 6
Low risk of corner case, but let's doc the notice and show the benefits
I think that we've settled on the design - might you be interested in taking this forward?

Sure but usually parameter parsing treats - and -- and as options; wsk action invoke x -p p -b where I intended to do a blocking invoke but forgot the parameter value seems like a bug in the parameter parsing to me. I'm willing to accept this as a feature just find it to be surprising behavior.

@style95 while it is true that a request may go to an unhealthy invoker topic, since messages in queue are persisted, a new invoker to replace the unhealthy one will pick up those messages and process them eventually. This can be achieved either by having a new invoker subscribe to the topic as needed. We had considered consumer groups in the past and more recently rethinking an approach around work stealing.

About the ping if you can ping from curl or browser, then it could be something going on with ansible client doing the curl
Check that you have the correct version of ansible 
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tools/ubuntu-setup/ansible.sh

If the system is not critical and your setting for development try to treardown all and deply fresh
```
wskdev teardown
rm ansible/db_local.ini
wskdev fresh
```
If you want to know if its a successful deploy deployment you can try invoking a simple action

I have not try docker 1.13 or the community edition of docker, I will suggest you use docker 1.12 since it's the version we are using today in OpenWhisk.

[ERROR] [system.err] Cannot connect to the Docker daemon. Is the docker daemon running on this host?

can you run docker ps?
@rabbah, you're right that those flags are only there for displaying usage information. Cobra doesn't actually process those flags as we do it manually.
